instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .

threads.title: water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no green light or power
threads.message:
Hello, as the titles says I got a water damage macbook pro (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) with no power or green light at the mag safe. My voltages on the main lines are the following: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0v, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v, and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 20.62v.  I have taken a look at my line <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and noticed that I have a short on <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_R_P</SIGNAL> which is why I have 0v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. During visual inspection, I noticed that <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> was completely blown (Pin 3 and 4 are completely gone). I have attached a pic for referral, I have tried to find this short but I haven't been successful. If Im not mistaken, the short im having is due to <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> blowing the pad and merging it to ground. If anyone can enlingthen me it will be greatly appreciated. Not sure how to approach this anymore. Thanks!

[ATTACH type="full" width="200px"]20679._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no green light or power
threads.message: Pretty sure there will be a short in the board  on that location. Start digging, but I think this is a write off.
